data.title: Make Telemetry Opt-In instead of Opt-Out
data.body: Telemetry should always be Opt-In.

data.title: Switch to npm5
data.body:
This should make installation time (and therefor builds) much faster and make lockfiles way more reliable, especially in regard to handling of optionalDependencies like fsevents.

I just ran `scripts/npm install` with npm5, which upgrades all the shrinkwrap files, then renamed then.
Additionally updated npm version in Travis and adapted gulpfiles.
I recommend merging this without squashing so the renames are recorded and not a huge delete+add.

data.title: Allow `files.encoding` to be set per programming language.
data.body:
The default file encoding cannot be set per programming language. This is a problem, because certain old languages force you to use old encodings.

Instead of manually having to reload the file in the correct encoding every time, I propose to allow the `files.encoding` setting to appear inside language specific settings.

```json
"[baan]": {
    "files.encoding": "iso88591"
}
```

When opening files of the types registered for the `baan` language, this would automatically set the file encoding to the specified value.

---

- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4|;

data.title: 'group' property is not an object literal in tasks.json
data.body:
Testing #29442:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2239563/27583962-8bbb35c2-5b36-11e7-8d57-4ad26040a816.png)

Intellisense on `group` property suggests only "kind" of a group, rather than an object literal with `kind` and `isPrimary`. Is it intended?
Also no documentation on `build` kind when typing `"group": "build"`.

data.title: Untitled editors should not restore when user confirmed to not save
data.body:
testing #29249

* open a no-workspace-window, create a new untitled file, type something
* create another no-workspace-window
* in the task bar select 'Close All Windows'
* from the first window you get prompted to save those files (that I find always unexpected)
* say not to save 
* reopen VS Code
* :bug: a no-workspace-window is created with an untitled but *empty* file

![jun-27-2017 12-46-20](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1794099/27584007-b2f8d0ea-5b36-11e7-82d4-e8fd906e9321.gif)

Currently in debug land I find it easier to add a new configuration due to some UX on top which helps with that.
Consider introducing the same in tasks land.

data.title: Cover multi root in automated smoke tests
data.body:
Currently we do not have multi-root coverage in our automated smoke test. We should add it once we have a way to enter multi-root without requiring a file dialog (which Spectron does not support atm).

I added it to our manual smoke test (cc @roblourens): https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/Smoke-Test#multi-root

/cc @michelkaporin

data.title: [I18N] Unresolved message placeholder
data.body: When opening a typescript file I get the message Note the brackets ```({1)}```. Seems to be a error in the order of the closing brackets.

data.title: Tasks 2.0.0 missing documentation
data.body:
Refs: #29442

Currently when a new tasks.json 2.0.0 is generated there is a link to the help docs, however those docs only talk about 0.1.0. So it seems like a use who wants to get informed about the new version is in a bad spot.

I propose we add a new section in our docs, and when we generate a 2.0.0 tasks.json to point to it

data.title: DebugSession.customRequest is not executing the command
Selection of problem matcher is not very intuitive when running a task

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Testing the following in #29442:
> Task > Run Build Task: shows the list again with the task run last listed under recently used tasks. This time select a problem matcher: Enusre that problems are detected (2) and that the tasks.json file opens with a configuration like this...

I was presented with a list that contains several items that look similar but do not work the same way
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2239563/27582143-38bdde48-5b30-11e7-9856-f44f8264b241.png)

To me `Gulp TSC Problems [$gulp-tsc]` and `TypeScript problems [$tsc]` problem matchers seemed semantically identical, so I picked up the first one just because I am using gulp task, and I needed to match TSC problems. It did not work, and only then I tried the second one, which worked and matched the problem.

If I wouldn't know what problem matchers do, I would not experience any difference whether I selected anything from the list or not.

Hence, two points:
1. If I select a problem matcher that does not find anything because it is wrong, I should have indication of this. 
Maybe 'Problems' tab can have a hint, pointing to problem matchers if a task was executed and no problems were detected? Other option is to echo information to the terminal that problem matcher did not find any problems. Otherwise it is very difficult to understand what was the impact of the selected problem matcher. 
Also having a badge with count of 'Problems found' on Problems tab in workbench pane would be beneficial, in order to see the result of problem matcher straight after running a task. Currently you have to move to 'Problems' tab to see problem count.
2. There should be a better way of semantic separation between those two tasks (and maybe any others). This is a difficult thing to do, and I cannot suggest anything at this time but we should be aware of it.

data.title: Escape 'scanning the build ouput' quick open -> run task is not canceld
data.body:
ref #29442

1. Run a task
2. When you are asked to choose how to scan the output -> press escape
3. The task is still run and the output will not be scanned. I would expect the run of the task is canceled

We also follow this pattern in other places where we have multiple quick open invocations, whenever one is canceled we cancel the original operation, so imho we should align here.

data.title: Task is not detected if gulp installed after 'Run Task' command was executed

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
Testing #29442.

1. Start with fresh workspace
2. Create gulpfile.js as mentioned in instructions.
3. Execute `Tasks: Run Task` command. -> No tasks found.
4. `npm install gulp` in workspace directory
5. Execution of the command again does not detect any tasks until you reload VS Code.

It would be great if it can pick up tasks without reloading after freshly installating gulp.

data.title: Preserve quick open input on Escape
data.body:
Related to #29247

I expected my input would be preserved even if I pressed <kbd>Escape</kbd> in quick open, when using `workbench.commandPalette.preserveInput`.

data.title: Thread name shows <No name> although other threads have a number as a name
data.body:
Tests: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29168

Set a breakpoint into one of the thread function: When the breakpoint is hit you get

![capture](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1931590/27580921-71c32fda-5b2c-11e7-85db-fdce6d6cca38.png)

Observe: the thread has <No Name> as the name. When the program starts the name of the thread is a number. I think if a thread has a name we should always use its name. If not we should use a consistent number.

data.title: Git: cannot sync while git status is running
data.body:
Very often I get into this situation:
* I start VS Code on Windows or Linux where I did not pull in a long time
* I see some incoming changes in the status bar
* I click on the sync button
* sync fails
* a lot more incoming changes are showing up after a short while

=> it looks like we try to pull changes in while a status is running?

Log:
```
Using git 2.11.0 from git
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git rev-parse --show-toplevel
git fetch
git config --get commit.template
git status -z -u
git show :foo_test.ts
git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
git rev-parse master
git rev-parse --symbolic-full-name --abbrev-ref master@{u}
git rev-list --left-right master...origin/master
git for-each-ref --format %(refname) %(objectname)
git remote --verbose
git show :foo_test.ts
git clean -f -q -- /home/ticino/development/vscode/Alles.txt /home/ticino/development/vscode/Alles1.txt /home/ticino/development/vscode/alles.txt /home/ticino/development/vscode/alles1.txt /home/ticino/development/vscode/foo.test.ts /home/ticino/development/vscode/foo.ts /home/ticino/development/vscode/foo_test.ts
git checkout -q -- /home/ticino/development/vscode/src/vs/base/common/comparers.ts /home/ticino/development/vscode/src/vs/workbench/electron-browser/main.ts
git status -z -u
git symbolic-ref --short HEAD
```

data.title: Adopt settings in search to be folder scoped
data.body:
Testing #29510

Following settings in Search can be customised at Folder level.

```
search.useIgnoreFilesByDefault
search.quickOpen.includeSymbols
```

data.body: Title says it all.

data.title: search.useIgnoreFilesByDefault is not having any impact in Single root workspace
data.body:
Testing #29510

- Open VS Code workspace in VS Code
- Open workspace settings and set `out*/**` to false in  `search.exclude` setting. This enables searching in `out` folder
- Search for search.exclude. Observe that you see results in `out` folder which is good.
- Open .gitignore file and notice that `out` folder is in ignore list
- Enable the setting `search.useIgnoreFilesByDefault` and do the search again on term search.exclude

Expected that results from `out` folder are ignored. But not.
It seems, the setting `search.useIgnoreFilesByDefault` has no impact on Search results.

I can only exclude ignore files by toggling the button in `files to exclude` section in `Search` view.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10746682/27580572-5059181a-5b2b-11e7-80ce-59b0eb0cd80c.png)
